title: Is Blackpink more famous than BTS after their 'Kill This Love' MV debut? - Quora

response.answer_text: Nah. I do understand that BLACKPINK’s music video blew up in terms of views, and now that it’s the third or fourth day, it still is increasing lots. But I don’t think the word “famous” necessarily has to do with the views right now. When I think of popularity, BTS still has the upper hand, as they’ve been for the past few years. BTS’s popularity has exploded ever since 2015, and the fandom is only growing both domestically and globally. I’m excited and nervous for their comeback on April 12, especially since they’re featuring Halsey, but I’’ll report my thoughts when the time comes for that. Though BLACKPINK’s popularity is also growing very quickly, if you had to compare BTS and BLACKPINK, you could look at it like a logistic curve of K-pop:  To me, BLACKPINK seems to be in the beginnings of the second section of the curve, where the growth is just beginning. BTS are well into the curve at the middle of the second section. So, as a short response, BLACKPINK aren’t more “famous” than BTS yet. They’re following a bit of the same curve of popularity but at different stages. And at their own pace/level. With that being said, there are are few things in my opinion that could be hindering BLACKPINK form embodying more popularity other than views. Of course, they’re immensely popular already. They’re the models for many CFs in Korea, are topping the charts when they release that once-a-year song, and are loved by so many abroad. They’re performing at Coachella this year, which will bound to increase their popularity even more. Coachella is where all of the influencers, celebrities on social media, and is the perfect formula for their success. Their music caters to a “western” audience relatively easily for K-pop, they have beautiful style, attitudes, charisma, ethereal faces, gorgeous bodies, and more that makes them even more likely to succeed during and after Coachella. However, I’ve noticed a few things that could be indicators that they’re not known to everyone, and they still a long way to go as a representation of their group and of K-pop. Their world tour reportedly did not sell out, they only have a few songs to perform at concerts, with many filler performances of cover songs and dances. They only come back once a year, and then they seemingly disappear from the media. Sometimes, the tease is too much. YG seems to overhype their songs too, raising very expectations, only to leave fans disappointed and fuel for some hate. I guess being famous is a double-edged sword. Seems like you can never have love without some hate.

I think this sums it up:  BTS is in red and Blackpink is in blue. This is a graph of the web searches worldwide for the past five years in all categories.  And in case you’re wondering what people were searching for during Blackpink’s comeback, BTS still wins. This graph is for the search trends for the past week (when Blackpink had their comeback) in the United States:  And this is the graph for the past week worldwide:  Though Blackpink did spike with their comeback April 4th, BTS still became the more popular trend just one day later on April 5th.  Conclusion: Blackpink has not become more famous than BTS with their comeback.
